Hello, everyone. I've been a fan of Adriene's since earlier last year. I just recently received my YTT-200 certification and am deepening my home practice. Now to my point: I have only gotten emotional during my practices twice in the whole two years I've been doing Yoga. Once was because I had a bad day and the other was because I just wasn't mentally present. Today, with this practice. Oh my. When we rocked back to Sukhasana and completed the cool down, my body just knew to put my hands on my knees in surrender. In Anjali Mudra, I immediately teared up but in Namaste, the tears were flowing every which way.  I struggle with letting my body lead, my mind always has the front seat. Today, some switch was flipped and it just felt really good to know that what I did, before you instructed it, was correct and that it felt amazing. Thank you for reading.

I am so grateful that you remind us that this is our yoga practice. In the past when I've yoga'd, I would feel immense pressure from the instructor to follow along with them exactly. If I modified a pose at all, I'd sometimes get a remark (addressed to the whole class) but something along the lines of, "if you want to truly benefit from this class you should follow along and tough out the harder poses, etc..". But how can an instructor know everyone's limits, injuries, and mental state.  I feel so free now and am more likely to "tough it out" because I feel supported. Thanks for everything you offer Adrienne! <3 Namaste!!

Hi Yogi's! I am having a difficult time planting my heals on my downward facing dog. I'm a pretty tall fella, 6'4", so when it comes to forward folds and downward dogs, my flexibility isn't exactly where I want it to be. Doesn't anyone have any tips for me to be practicing daily to help with this?

I found it just came over time! It took me 6 months of daily yoga but now my feet finally touch the floor! I found it is just like any flexibility training meaning it just takes time. However, I did find it sped up a little bit when in every downward dog I would actively try to reach my heels to the floor, building the flexibility that way! Also bringing your feet a little closer to your hands can help.

during the session:
Adriene: move along with your breath, at the same rhythm

Today I was having a bit of trouble finding those deep, satisfying breaths that I like to get. Sometimes I get acid reflux and gas problems, but I was making my best effort to just be mindful of what was going on. My breathing felt better by the end of the practice. I felt good about how my body and breath were flowing together in the practice despite being unable to take the deeper breaths that I wanted.

As someone who practices daily I have a hard time understanding how that is comfortable in Sukhasana which means "easy or comfort pose." I hope in her next series that she learns to take her feet underneath the knees which will help her bring her knees down and help maintain the pose in a way that is healing to the body. In other news, vinyasa is not my jam but I'm still doing this series to try for myself but if it weren't for my base in the Iyengar Yoga tradition I think I might have really hurt my left wrist this morning.

I have been doing yoga on and off for years, kept getting hurt trying to "keep up" with others in the class. I‚Äôm finding it really hard to overcome that inner resistance that doesn‚Äôt want to let go or flow but is instead questioning my intention, purpose and focus. Any tips for how to get rid of this inner critic? X

I now tell myself it's normal to feel those feelings. When I first began my practice my inner critic was in charge for a very long time. It was not until I allowed the thought to exist then pass (I still have the thoughts, but they quickly leave) that I was able to understand that my thoughts are not in control of me, they are simply thoughts.

I started doing Yoga With Adriene last week when I started feeling consistent back pain around the T10/T11. I wasn‚Äôt sure if it was because of my strenuous exercise or because I‚Äôm overweight or because of my myomas, or a combination of two or more of those. I‚Äôm 32 years old and I feel like a wreck, health-wise. All I know is that after doing 3 or 4 of her videos, I decided to stop my strenuous workout (30 mins cardio reaching a heart rate of 165bpm + 1 hr strength exercises, 5 days a week) and I decided to do dedicate. I‚Äôm only on day 5, but I feel better. I‚Äôll start watching my diet next week. I have been eating pretty much anything lately. I hope I‚Äôll feel much better once I eat clean and continue doing dedicate. Adriene, please continue doing these free videos. You‚Äôre changing lives for the better. And to everyone else who are thinking of doing this or saying to themselves, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll do this, just not now yet‚Äù, a piece of unsolicited advise - making the decision to wear something comfy and hopping on your mats, might just be the best decision you‚Äôll do for your health. Don‚Äôt wait. Just do it! And feel the difference even on day 1. As early as day 1, I was reminded that mindful breathing brings about healing. Doing dedicate allowed me to practice mindful breathing more religiously.

Coming back to yoga at 68 after a few years away because of a series of unrelated little injuries.  I've lost a lot of muscle mass in the last three or four years away, and the strength to come off the floor is gone. I have to come into Downward Dog from cobra by coming up on knees rather than pushing directly back. I'm  feeling like this is going  a little too fast but I'm making adjustments and know I can always do the 30 days over and over until I get those heels down on the floor and am able to step directly into forward bend from plank, one foot at a time, but in the meantime I'm walking up and doing it at my pace.  I know from past experience this isn't the goal, but the goal  is to focus on the moment.  I'm getting the benefits, and before I know it I will be doing things I thought were impossible.

Being completely honest here: I tried one of your yoga 30 day practices last year and failed. I managed to make it to day 26 or something, but it took me 4 months to do it. I had fallen and injured my right knee, so even basic table top was out of the question. Waited for my knee to heal, then I found out I needed my gallbladder out stat. Kept writing in my calendar to start doing yoga again, and I finally made it at the beginning of February. It wasn't planned really, but I follow you on facebook and one of your videos started playing and it made me miss (despite the physical endurance) how fun your videos are! Started February 2nd, and plan on making it through the 30 days even if I have to take a break once in awhile. I also deal with migraines and a back issue (it's complicated), so I might have to actually slow the speed of your videos down. I just want to focus on moving slowly but with purpose and save myself from hurting my back. From the bottom of my heart, thank you so much for doing these videos for people like me. You have a beautiful soul! Love seeing Benji photobombing (ha, videobombing?) every once in awhile.

So I teach exercise classes (up to 4 hours a day) and lift weights. Everyone considers me 'the fitness lady' but my body is telling me otherwise. I started this dedicate journey bc my nerves down the right side of my back have become compressed, and my left shoulder constantly aches. So I've stopped going to the gym, and after day 4 I noticed my back has aligned really well and my shoulder has started to feel less painful (breathing into the pain, rather than being frustrated with it is helping). I'm now considering getting rid of my gym membership, swapping to martial arts & just doing yoga with Adriene! I think what I'm learning is that the premise of weightlifting is just unsustainable- keep tearing your muscles, keep adding the weights even when your body is telling you otherwise, keep pushing yourself. When really we need to listen to our bodies & should feel energised after exercise. What's the point of lifting really heavy if you feel completely burnt out after and need to supplement to get through it? Doesn't sound like health to me.

Three weeks ago, my boyfriend of over three years ended our relationship, completely out of the blue. Whether it's for work, just to get through your day (or in my case: to get through that passage in the Donizetti piece that has had me worked up this whole week) trust in the breath and your foundation. Thank you for your words of wisdom, Adriene

Thurs., 1/17/19:  Lovely flow. I'm picking back up on the subtleties of yoga asanas, like cycling the energy from toes to fingers and really breathing into those poses. It may come as a shock, but actually the hardest pose is towards the beginning for me, where we are just pausing in an arms-up position while sitting down. Most yoga practices that I've done only stay in those poses for approximately one breath and then you move on to the next pose, so you get distracted with the movement and forget your discomfort. I really like getting a chance to explore more of the minute spaces where I might be tight and then getting to loosen them, no matter how obscure they may be. After today's practice, I feel a lot more spacious, namaste c:
These are really great. Got my fianc√© doing it too with me after the kids are in bed!

I legit don't think I've ever commented on a youtube video before but I just had to for this series. I have never been particularly physically active in my life, which gave me concerns starting this series, not to mention that I started a bit late in the game (5 days ago). Adriene makes things so approachable that even if I can't flow nicely, or do the moves the exact same way due to my physical limitations, I find myself looking forward to practicing. I hope that I can stick with this long term because already I am feeling muscles being used that haven't been used in years, and feeling good about embracing a practice.

Blessed be friends. You are a beautiful miracle in my life, this community, this forum. In a world more willing to medicate someone rather than find the root of their problems, you have been my first ray of light in many years. Doctors had me convinced my neurological deterioration was a death sentence, especially because i cant take medications. Than after years of suffering with pain and everything that comes with it, i stumbled on accident, and found yoga with adrienne. You are so much more then the loving practice you are sharing with us, you are hope and goodness and i will never really no you, and you will never no me, but Adrienne you have saved me in a way i didnt know i could be saved. You showed me yoga isnt a rush or a destination, but a beautiful journey of self discovery and strength and for that i will always be grateful for you in this life. Ever growing. Blessed be. Peace.

When I woke up this morning with a head cold, one of the things that I was most disappointed about was that I would be missing a day so early on especially given that this was a faster, more intense flow practice. But as the day went on, I decided that for once I would give it a try, promising to take all the easiest versions and giving myself permission to spend half of it in child's pose if I needed to or even stopping.¬†

I'm glad to say that I was able to do the practice even though I had to dial it back and that doing so is a big milestone for me. I really hope that this can be the first year that I can complete the whole 30 days on their individual days but even if it isn't, whatever I can manage, like I did today, will be worthwhile compared to none at all.

I was having issues syncing my breath with my movements (mostly because I was breathing so hard from the exercise) and I basically fell out of one of the lunges because I was shaking so bad. I started to get mad at myself, but then my dog came over and laid down next to me and I took that as I sign of support. Instead of giving up I gave myself a second and then jumped back into the practice. At the end, I took a minute to lay on the floor with my dog and think of the parts of today's practice where I could feel myself getting stronger and not struggling as much (my arms aren't shaking in tabletop or downward dog as much as they were on day 1 and 2) and now I am excited to continue on and keep getting stronger and I will keep meeting my body where it is at now.

Today I really had a moment of realizing how far I have come in my yoga practice. I was sitting in the very beginning, and realized that I am using yoga as a tool to calm myself, a way to feel strong and always a way to try and accept myself without needing to constantly judge. The first year I tried this, 2016, I tried to muscle through, and when I missed a day I would make it up the next day, and do two or three videos trying to "catch up". I learned over time, though, that while completing the videos is important, it is more important to encourage myself. So instead of beating myself down, each day, after I complete a practice, I tell myseld, "Good job! You've done 5 days so far! Way to go!"
I'm just trying to work on being present in each moment and stop worrying about the past or the future. It's a lot of work. But you're amazing Adriene, and I cannot express how grateful I am that you create this gift, for us, every year- millions of people, many of whom you've never met, have been impacted by you and your amazing spirit. Please keep giving and know that you have made the world a much brighter, better place for me. <3

Our family dog of almost 14 years passed away unexpectedly last night (he‚Äôd been completely fine, still healthy despite his age at his last vet check last year). Needless to say we‚Äôre pretty heartbroken (husband and two teenage sons). Everyone is at work (or away at university) today and I‚Äôm kind of wandering around my house aimlessly. Today, though, marked day 66 of 66 of Yoga with Adriene for me, and this is the one thing I knew I ‚Äòhad‚Äô to do today to keep the chain going and the one thing I knew would make me feel at least a little bit better. It did. Thank you, Adriene, for helping me through a tough day, and also for the way following you for 66 days straight is changing so many aspects of my life. Give Benji an extra hug for me - and anyone else who reads this who has pets. You just never know... And lots of love and cheers to everyone on the Yoga with Adriene bandwagon. If you‚Äôre new to it, keep at it - showing up every day really is life changing. Even with tears landing on my mat today, it gave me solace.

Instead of putting your weight at the base of your palms (where your palm meets your writs), put your weight at the top of your palm, where your fingers are.  This has made a HUGE difference for me, as I too was having sore wrists.
